dataList.title: LCE Department
dataList.content: Arriving at the LCE Department.
Oi... What in the...
The sight that greeted us was nothing like what we remembered from our last visit for the regular check-up.
... We're too late.
I thought HQ's reinforcements would be holding the line... or at the very least, that I'd walk into a battle...
... Yet there was nobody left standing, much less making a run for it.
All we could see were bodies slumped along the floor, filling the corridor in motionless silence.
This... This is just awful... I never thought the ship would go down this badly...
Faust, have you got any idea how many of the LCE are actually combat-ready?

The LCE... tends to encounter more combat tryouts and experiments compared to the other research-focused departments. The vast majority of its employees are required to have completed basic training pertaining to the aforementioned.
As for the E.G.O equipments... Although the current research and extraction process may be sophisticated enough to see some considerable results in combat,
it would seem that they were ill-equipped to handle a pre-planned ambush such as this.
Fat chance those lab nerds could do anything in a real fight, let alone against the Spiders out on the prowl.
The memories came flooding back—researchers jotting down our check-up results on piles of paper, and Hohenheim, with his droopy, tired eyes, leafing through the files.
We'd barely exchanged goodbyes when he rounded up the burnt-out lab staff, who were already pulling their hair out from the sheer level of stress, to oversee another experiment in progress.
<Meursault. If you happen to notice anyone who... looks like Hohenheim... let me know ASAP.>
I have identified three bodies in various states that make immediate recognition challenging. However, their stature and attire make it extremely unlikely that any of them are Hohenheim.
From the looks of it... they probably didn't even get the chance to put up any meaningful resistance before they were killed.
With a glum look in his eyes, Gregor examined the bodies strewn across the floor.
Out of 32 bodies, 26 show identical physical trauma.
<Identical...?>

Every one of them has a spiral-shaped perforation at the center of the chest, over where the heart is. Their cause of death seems to be the same type of "spiral" weapon they are holding in their hands, Manager.
These spirals... I think they pulled them out themselves... but why would...
... Soft.
Ryōshū cast her gaze down, quietly eyeing her palm.
From the cryptic words and the contemplative look on her face,
I could easily guess that she was taking a trip through the shadows of her past...
... touching an invisible object with her palm and feeling its texture, in search of something that should have been there in her hands.
And I've been through enough to know that we would be revisiting her past together.
However...
What I witnessed was completely different from the memories of the other Sinners I'd seen so far.
The vision I saw was completely fragmented....
... as if a blade had cut up her memories into pieces.
Within Ryōshū's memories, something did indeed rest in her palm. However...
I couldn't even make out whether its hue was closer to black or white.
Was it some kind of food? A weapon, or something else entirely?
Even the expression that crossed her face when she saw it and the words that slipped from her lips in that moment escaped me.
One thing I saw for sure, though...
... was that the person who, in all likelihood, had given it to her...
... was letting out a lazy puff of smoke swirling into the air,
watching Ryōshū's reaction in complete ease.
I gazed back upon the cryptic scenes of Ryōshū's memory that flashed before my eyes.
<Ryōshū? Is there anything you remember?>
... "Saru."
That name's all I can remember.
<You mean...>
As you've seen, Clock, my mind has been hacked to tatters.
The sequence and the shapes... Everything is in tangles.
There is nothing I can explain about my memory.
It seems we've gotten the gist of the situation. The worst-case scenario here would be...
... a breach from the outside happening while Abnormalities, Distortions, and Peccatula break containment all at once.
Whoa. Now that's a situation I really don't even want to think about... We'd be fighting trespassers and all kinds of monsters broken loose!
Precisely. That sums up our present circumstance.
Right...
Outis wasted no time to deliver the conclusion that'd kill everyone's morale.
Let's start from the beginning.
First, the LCE Department found itself under attack by a group of unidentified hostiles 2 hours prior.
The weapons used to massacre the researchers... are not uniform. The victims appear to have been killed with a various assortment of arms.
My darling daughter.
Eyes on me. When using straight weapons that leave the farthest-reaching arcs...
Eyes on me. When using weapons that kill with the tiniest incisions...
Eyes on me. When using flexible weapons that crush anything they make contact with...
What a tangled mess, just like that bastard.
Hard to tell what kind of weapons were used here... Damn.
Ryōshū whipped her hair back, furrowing her eyebrows in annoyance.
... Safe to say that the killer is adept with at least three different types of weapons.
Moving on...
This was a surprise attack carried out without any delay whatsoever, and the LCE had no time to even plan a counterattack. It was, for lack of a better word, a massacre.
Now, here's something that demands our attention.
It appears the invaders had the Abnormality containment units opened... only after they confirmed that the surprise attack had been carried out successfully.
... That sure is fishy.
I mean... shouldn't it be the other way around?
Unlock the containment units first, let the monsters wreak havoc through the facility... then swoop in during the chaos and finish off the stragglers. That'd be the easier course of action.
Indeed. The enemy's strategy is highly unusual.
As for why they resorted to such an unusual move, there are two plausible explanations.
Firstly, that the enemy may be comprised of fighters skilled enough to forgo a diversion tactic.
You mean there could be more... who are as strong as the woman in the truck who kidnapped Charon...?
Mm. Secondly...
That the enemy may have purposefully unleashed the Abnormalities from the cages as a follow-up measure.
Follow-up measure...? Art thou implying those villains sought to disguise their vile attack?!

No, the chance of a cover-up is almost nonexistent. Unless they had precise knowledge of scavenger Abnormalities that could devour the corpses clean, the enemy would never have left such identifiable wounds on their victims.
It makes more sense that their goal was to delay HQ's main reinforcements and keep them from reaching the scene on time as we did.
A delay tactic... I see. Maybe they were looking for something?
Possibly. They must've had a specific objective in mind when they broke through.
Which means whatever they're looking for... should be here somewhere.
Something elusive and so well-hidden that they had to distract us just to buy themselves some time.
... We need to hurry, then.
